text:
<@URB31QKM4> I've been onboarding a new editor (for CXL) _and_ vetting and overseeing a bunch of freelance editors recently (for Adeft, a new product).

A few random learnings:

• There's no way to skip the onboarding phase entirely. It takes a bit of time. We've tried to expedite this by getting editors as many "reps" as possible, which sometimes tasks them with things tangential to their role. For example, our in-house editor updates 4-5 posts per week for us, which basically 3X's the number of posts he touches each week---far more exposure to nebulous elements (like tone) compared to what he'd get just working on new stuff.
• Loom videos are really, really good ways to share the thought processes behind your editorial sensibility (and often quicker than leaving comments). We've been able to create a lot of "Aha!" moments for editors by thinking out loud through how we might edit an outline or post in a 5-10 min video (e.g., the things we look at and the order we look at them, potential green/yellow/red flags, questions or comments we might have for the author---and why).
• We've more or less given up on finding unicorn editors (for Adeft) who can provide subject-matter expert (SME)-level edits to content (based on years of experience _doing_ something, not just writing about it) and be super attuned to more traditional copy edits and style guide things. Our solution is a tiered system in which we expect every piece of content on Adeft to go through a series of editors: an initial review by a freelance editor who knows something about the marketing space (but wouldn't qualify as an expert practitioner), an SME review for content accuracy, and a final review by a technical writer/old-school copyeditor-type person. (This isn't quite as expensive as it sounds, especially if the original author of the content is an SME.)
• We've always had more success hiring editors who have some experience as practitioners vs. editors who don't know the space. It's easier to train someone up on your writing style than the tofu-and-potatoes of the content.
• You get what you pay for.
